citation.article-title: Caloramator indicus sp. nov., a new thermophilic anaerobic bacterium isolated from the deep-seated nonvolcanically heated waters of an Indian artesian aquifer.

p.s: Description of Caloramator indicus sp. nov.
Caloramator indicus (in'di.cus. M.L. gen. n. indicus, of India, the country from which the organism was isolated)
Rods to filamentous cells that are 10 to 100 μm long by 0.6 to 0.8 μm wide.
The optimum temperature for growth is 60 to 65°C, and no growth occurs at temperatures below 37°C or above 75°C.
The optimum pH is between 7.5 and 8.1, and no growth occurs at pH values below 6.2 or above 9.2.
Utilizes glucose, amylopectin, starch, amylose, dextrin, cellobiose, fructose, lactose, mannose, and sucrose.
Produces ethanol, acetate, lactate, CO2, and H2 during fermentation on glucose.
Cellulose, dextran, and chitin are not fermented.
Requires Trypticase peptone and/or yeast extract for growth on carbohydrates; both of these compounds can also be utilized in the absence of carbohydrates.
Growth is inhibited by tetracycline, penicillin G, chloramphenicol, novobiocin, polymyxin B, and rifampin.
The G+C content of the DNA is 25.6 ± 0.3 mol%, as determined by thermal denaturation.
Phylogenetically related to Caloramator fervidus on the basis of the results of a 16s rRNA sequence analysis.
The habitat is nonvolcanically heated waters that are hot because of the great depth of the aquifer.
The location where the type strain was obtained is in Surat District, Gujarat State, India.
The type strain is strain IndiB4 (= ACM 3982).
